signals.title: Meta's $1.5 Billion, 1 GW AI Data Centre in Texas with Pre-Built Grid Infrastructure
signals.description: Meta Platforms announced an initial investment of over $1.5 billion for a new AI-optimised data centre in El Paso, Texas, designed to scale to 1 gigawatt (GW) of capacity, with direct funding of new grid infrastructure including transmission lines and substations.
signals.context: Demonstrates hyperscaler willingness to fund public energy infrastructure to accelerate deployment timelines, whether through intentional coordination or emergent market adaptation.

signals.title: OpenAI-Broadcom 10 GW Custom AI Accelerator Partnership
signals.description: OpenAI and Broadcom announced a strategic collaboration to co-develop and deploy 10 gigawatts (GW) of custom AI accelerators. The chips are designed by OpenAI and optimised for AI inference workloads at unprecedented scale.
signals.context: Represents a shift towards hardware sovereignty and challenges NVIDIA's infrastructure dominance, consistent with either strategic coordination or convergent market evolution towards computational independence.

signals.title: UK-U.S. Tech Prosperity Deal: £31 Billion Private Investment Framework
signals.description: During President Trump's September 2025 UK state visit, Britain and the U.S. announced the Tech Prosperity Deal, a joint technology partnership. Under this government-brokered framework, U.S. tech firms (Microsoft, NVIDIA, Google, CoreWeave, and others) pledged £31 billion towards UK AI infrastructure, including data centres, chips, and research facilities. The deal also establishes UK-U.S. collaboration on AI, quantum computing, and nuclear energy research.
signals.context: Demonstrates significant private-sector investment in AI infrastructure coordinated through bilateral government partnership framework, establishing precedent for public-private coordination in advanced technology development.

signals.title: U.S. Senate Advances Guaranteeing Access and Innovation for National AI (GAIN) Act
signals.description: The U.S. Senate advanced the Guaranteeing Access and Innovation for National AI (GAIN) Act on October 10, 2025, as part of the FY2026 National Defence Authorization Act. The legislation mandates that AI chip manufacturers give U.S. buyers priority access to advanced processors through an 'America-First Right of Refusal' before allowing exports to foreign adversaries. Exporters must obtain licences and certify no U.S. customer backlog exists before shipping high-end chips abroad.
signals.context: Actively reshapes global AI supply chains by legally prioritising domestic chip access, representing clear fragmentation pressure consistent with protectionist technology sovereignty policies rather than international coordination.

calculation_summary.adjustment_note: Conservative calibration for launch assessment allows natural equilibrium discovery through signal accumulation

api_info.correction_note: Signal #3 reclassified from Coordination Mechanism (W:4) to Infrastructure Commitment (W:3) following source verification
